commit_message:
log: Spooling logger and manager

In the Nova scheduler, a lot of logs are produced per request which
are never looked at. We could cache these log records in memory and
only handle them if the overall request fails.

This patch provides a SpoolManager which you can set up for EG 'api'
requests. You can then ask it for a SpoolLogger, which will get a name
like "spool.api.<request id>". You pass this logger to the request
processor, from which it will cache log records, and if there is an
exception you call #flush on it. The log records will be released and
propagate up to the "spool.api" logger, then "spool", then the root
logger. Configure these with your logging config file as usual.

If flush is not called then the log records will be collected when the
last hard reference to the SpoolLogger is removed. If you're worried
about lingering logger references, you can call clear to wipe the
records once you know you no longer need them.

Please check carefully for race conditions and memory leaks.

Implements: blueprint log-spooling
Change-Id: Ia9e1566743015440f029f161b10252ae427c07d8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.log refs/changes/62/316162/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import collections import cPickle import logging import weakref class SpoolHandler(logging.Handler): """Holds log records in memory until flushed.""" def __init__(self, manager): """Don't call this directly, use a SpoolManager.""" super(SpoolHandler, self).__init__() self.manager = manager self.records = collections.deque() self.bytes = 0 self.createLock() def emit(self, record): """Add a record to the spool. If the new record means the spool is too big, limits will be enforced. """ size = None if self.manager.max_bytes: size = len(cPickle.dumps(record)) self.records.append((record, size)) if size: self.bytes += size self.enforce_limit() def flush(self): """Flush records from the spool.""" self.acquire() count = len(self.records) targets = list(self.manager.targets) for recnum in range(count): record = self._popleft() for target in targets: target.handle(record) self.release() def _enforce_limit(self): self.acquire() if self.manager.max_bytes: while self.bytes > self.manager.max_bytes: self._popleft() if self.manager.max_records: while len(self.records) > self.manager.max_records: self._popleft() self.release() def _popleft(self): record, size = self.records.popleft() if size: self.bytes -= size class SpoolManager(object): """Manages spools for a set of requests. Use one SpoolManager per type of request, for example 'api' or 'scheduler'. """ def __init__(self, slug, max_bytes=0, max_records=0): """Constructor. :param slug: Identifies the type of request these spools will handle, EG 'api'. :param max_bytes: Limits the size of spools handled by this manager. :param max_records: Limits the size of spools handled by this manager. """ self._slug = slug self.max_bytes = max_bytes self.max_records = max_records self._loggers = {} self._targets = [] @property def slug(self): return self._slug @property def targets(self): """The handlers managed spools will emit to. Add at least one handler or flushing spools will eliminate records. """ return self._targets def get_spool(self, unique): """Returns a new or existing spooling logger. The logger will have a single SpoolHandler attached and a flush method. When you flush the logger, this manager's targets will be asked to emit the spooled log records. :param unique: A request ID or other UUID. """ ref = self._loggers.get(unique) if ref: return ref() def _del(it): del self._loggers[unique] handler = SpoolHandler(self) logger = logging.getLogger('spool.%s.%s' % (self._slug, unique)) logger.propagate = 0 logger.addHandler(handler) logger.flush = lambda: handler.flush() self._loggers[unique] = weakref.ref(logger, _del) return logger def each_spool(self): """Generates each (unique, logger) pair. Loggers are held with weak references so items may disappear out of this list when the garbage collector runs. This means they are no longer active.""" for unique in sorted(self._loggers): yield unique, self._loggers[unique]()

commit_message:
VNC: Strip cookies containing brackets

Cookies with [ or ] characters in cause the VNC proxy server
to fail to obtain the token cookie. This is due to a bug in
python 2.7.9: https://bugs.python.org/issue22931

This patch strips any cookies containing '[' or ']'.

Change-Id: Ic13c49e95996ee69a025c0ce3d34315f06d4ab07
Co-Authored-By: Alexis Lee <lxsli@hpe.com>
Closes-Bug: #1496932

commit_message:
Cleanup: Remove useless function data()

StubGlanceClient.data() is strange. It always returns [].
And furthermore, it is not used anywhere. So remove it.

Change-Id: Iec3c2bba984a77eed8603f14fcde2c6d61df241a

commit_message:
Support checking multiple endpoints

Currently the agent only supports checking for a single endpoint,
which it assumes is the API. Some services, for example Nova, are
composed of several smaller services (API, scheduler, conductor) and
we'd like to check that each of those are up. Also, some operators use
VIPs in front of their services and may want to monitor those in
addition to the internal endpoint.

Change-Id: I8475151b4bf9ca1b45b2886960c358f5de3cda04

commit_message:
Allow bypass of listening check

Some services may want to monitor endpoints whether they're running or
not. This adds a "listen_check"=True parameter to endpoints which, if
False, will bypass the listening check.

Change-Id: I9ed404e5c3c0f0cb193504d7472d956839ebbeb6

commit_message:
Clean up argparse declaration

I've attempted to sort the options into broad sections, making it
easier to find an option. I removed a couple of redundant directives
(EG default=False with action='store_true'). I put the option names
and params on one line with the help text last. I removed the
unnecessary +s between literal strings, Python will parse two strings
adjoined only by whitespace as a single literal.

Altogether I find this makes them easier to read, I hope you agree.

Change-Id: Ib5a9eec07cca7e6cec723393cab6c50ac24a4ee3

" "Required only if insecure is set to False") parser.add_argument( '--insecure', default=False, help="Set whether certificates are used for Keystone authentication") # Execution control parser.add_argument( '--skip_enable', action="store_true", help="By default the service is enabled, " "which requires the script run as root. Set this to skip that step.") parser.add_argument( '--install_plugins_only', action="store_true", help="Only update plugin configuration, do not configure services, users, etc." " or restart services") parser.add_argument( '--system_only', action="store_true", default=False, help="Setup the service but only configure the base config and system " "metrics (cpu, disk, load, memory, network).") parser.add_argument( '-d', '--detection_plugins', nargs='*', help="Skip base config and service setup and only configure this space " "separated list. subject: log: Freeze log records before spooling
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-06-24 13:48:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.log/commit/60f55c5770dae857995aaf202783545e29397465', 'message': "log: Freeze log records before spooling

It's common to pass an object (EG an instance) as part of a log
record, then mutate that object. This isn't a problem normally as the
log record has already been formatted and emitted but if we're going
to spool log records, this could lead to misleading logs.

Allow a 'freezer' function to be provided, either on the SpoolManager
or via the 'spooling' context manager. This function must return a
record which will not mutate. copy.deepcopy is a valid freezer
function. Optionally, it may also prune the record so it takes less
memory to spool, providing all the information required by the
formatter(s) is retained. If no function is supplied, the record must
not be mutated (nor any object it refers to).

Implements: blueprint log-spooling
Change-Id: I940223628937b394e9b68005574f2b32a34de2af

commit_message:
log: Freeze log records before spooling

It's common to pass an object (EG an instance) as part of a log
record, then mutate that object. This isn't a problem normally as the
log record has already been formatted and emitted but if we're going
to spool log records, this could lead to misleading logs.

Allow a 'freezer' function to be provided, either on the SpoolManager
or via the 'spooling' context manager. This function must return a
record which will not mutate. copy.deepcopy is a valid freezer
function. Optionally, it may also prune the record so it takes less
memory to spool, providing all the information required by the
formatter(s) is retained. If no function is supplied, the record must
not be mutated (nor any object it refers to).

Implements: blueprint log-spooling
Change-Id: I940223628937b394e9b68005574f2b32a34de2af
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.log refs/changes/11/333911/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Tighten up the Python

Looking at the code with an eye to a change, I saw some opportunities
for improvement. I've used list comprehensions to get rid of long-form
loops and established some instance variables as lists to get rid of
look-before-we-leap checks.

The __init__ method now accepts keyword arguments as keyword arguments
rather than just via dict.

Change-Id: Ie8b4282148b392f4123bd19e984d085df2cc6547
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-agent refs/changes/21/336621/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def __init__(self, kwargs, **kws): combi = dict(kwargs) combi.update(kws) self.service_name = combi['service_name'] args = combi.get('args') if isinstance(args, str): combi.update(dict(item.split('=') for item in args.split())) self.process_names = ServicePlugin._get_list_arg(combi, 'process_names') self.file_dirs_names = combi.get('file_dirs_names') or [] self.directory_names = ServicePlugin._get_list_arg(combi, 'directory_names') self.service_api_url = combi.get('service_api_url') self.search_pattern = combi.get('search_pattern') overwrite = combi['overwrite'] template_dir = combi['template_dir'], super(ServicePlugin, self).__init__(template_dir, overwrite, args) @staticmethod def _get_list_arg(combi, name): rv = combi.get(name) if isinstance(rv, str): return rv.split(',') elif isinstance(rv, list): return rv elif rv is None: return [] raise TypeError("{0} is not a list".format(name)) self.found_processes = [p for p in self.process_names if find_process_cmdline(p)] self.available = (self.found_processes or self.file_dirs_names or self.directory_names) for process in self.found_processes: # Watch the service processes log.info("\tMonitoring the {0} {1} process.".format(process, self.service_name)) config.merge(watch_process([process], self.service_name, process, exact_match=False)) for file_dir_name in self.file_dirs_names: # Watch file size file_dir = file_dir_name[0] file_names = file_dir_name[1] if len(file_dir_name) == 3: file_recursive = file_dir_name[2] else: file_recursive = False if file_names == ['*']: log.info("\tMonitoring the size of all the files in the " "directory {0}.".format(file_dir)) else: log.info("\tMonitoring the size of files {0} in the " "directory {1}.".format(", ".join(str(name) for name in file_names), file_dir)) config.merge(watch_file_size(file_dir, file_names, file_recursive, self.service_name)) for dir_name in self.directory_names: log.info("\tMonitoring the size of directory {0}.".format( dir_name)) config.merge(watch_directory(dir_name, self.service_name)) log.info("\tConfiguring an http_check for the {0} API.".format(self.service_name)) api_url = self.check_listening(self.service_api_url) if api_url: def check_listening(self, endpoint): # Check there is something listening on the host/port parsed = urlparse.urlparse(self.service_api_url) host, port = parsed.netloc.split(':') listening = [c.laddr[0] for c in psutil.net_connections() if c.status == psutil.CONN_LISTEN and c.laddr[1] == int(port)] if not listening: log.info("\tNo process found listening on {0} " "skipping setup of http_check.".format(port)) return None # commit_message:
log: Limit spools in bytes

The count of records is a poor measure of the amount of memory
consumed. I imagine operators would prefer to limit their spools to
say 10MB each, instead of say 1000 records and hope that each record
is under 10KB.

This patch adds a means of so limiting, using pymple's asizeof method
to recursively size the log record. This is done after freezing, which
gives projects a chance to cut out unnecessary information.

Implements: blueprint log-spooling
Change-Id: I5a7c35610ea688ace03dc3bda5a265cd2c86773d

commit_message:
log: SpoolFilter and 'spooling' context manager

Having spools is all very well but how do you get messages logged to
normal loggers into the right spools? This patch adds a SpoolFilter to
the global filter which diverts messages with request_ids registered
with context manager to the registered spool.

Implements: blueprint log-spooling
Change-Id: Ia845f05e146b182f44e4ec89c131094a9cfb2d6c

commit_message:
log: Add a global filter

Victor identified on Ic58dafceefde1b109721a58631c223522bf4cc9c that
log filters are only applied by the logger they are added to. That is,
if you apply a filter to the root logger, it's only checked for
records that are sent directly to the root logger. It is not checked
for records that propagate there.

This patch adds a global filter, which is applied to every logger. You
can then add filters to the global filter, which will run on every
record, regardless of which logger they are sent to. Three stages of
filter are offered, with the suggestion that 'pre' and 'post' filters
are used to modify the record while 'mid' filters actually filter or
divert records.

Change-Id: Ibce8a61df5a07225ff4d240a644a042908b9741d
Co-Authored-By: Victor Stinner <vstinner@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add Apache 2.0 license to source file

As per OpenStack licensing guide lines [1]:
[H102 H103] Newly contributed Source Code should be licensed under
the Apache 2.0 license.
[H104] Files with no code shouldn't contain any license header nor
comments, and must be left completely empty.

[1] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/#openstack-licensing

Change-Id: Ic7c1319b81acfadc5d9a3566fee54d08741a7b73
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/97/379197/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Test <all-in> matches elements, not substrings
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-07-08 14:19:40.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/scheduler/filters/test_extra_specs_ops.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/15fdb1477430f31b4f963787a9b6ce348e819a84', 'message': 'Test <all-in> matches elements, not substrings

The tests for the <all-in> filter operator were matching its inputs
against stringified lists ("['aes', 'mmx']" rather than ['aes', 'mmx']),
so were actually testing for substring matching. See
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-July/098936.html
for discussion. This patch passes a list instead of a stringified list
to the matcher, to test that <all-in> behaves correctly when matching
against lists of strings.

Change-Id: I2f5a86b0e9596d901e2cb7dc943ea7d8a2ebc191
'}]
commit_message:
Test <all-in> matches elements, not substrings

The tests for the <all-in> filter operator were matching its inputs
against stringified lists ("['aes', 'mmx']" rather than ['aes', 'mmx']),
so were actually testing for substring matching. See
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2016-July/098936.html
for discussion. This patch passes a list instead of a stringified list
to the matcher, to test that <all-in> behaves correctly when matching
against lists of strings.

Change-Id: I2f5a86b0e9596d901e2cb7dc943ea7d8a2ebc191
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/76/339576/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Add retries for murano-dbmanage task
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-21 15:57:59.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/d17cc0af0088df90dfa084ab8153f5113a08354c', 'message': 'Add retries for murano-dbmanage task

Keystone-manage db_sync fails without any chance to retry via
additional puppet runs if it was completed successfully on the
first run. Adding retries reduces the likelihood that deployment fails.

Change-Id: I567c0c944b308db344326ad0555e98e21f422236
Related-bug: #1620268
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-09-21 16:09:20.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library/commit/a1c33839b0dc6dfd2776b9546450d0adb6f3c2d7', 'message': 'Add retries for murano-dbmanage task

Murano-dbmanage fails without any chance to retry via
additional puppet runs if it was completed successfully on the
first run. Adding retries reduces the likelihood that deployment fails.

commit_message:
Add retries for murano-dbmanage task

Murano-dbmanage fails without any chance to retry via
additional puppet runs if it was completed successfully on the
first run. Adding retries reduces the likelihood that deployment fails.

Change-Id: I567c0c944b308db344326ad0555e98e21f422236
Related-bug: #1620268

commit_message:
tempest-cleanup can only be invoked as tempest cleanup

The CLI entry point removed here points to the main() class which was removed
so that tempest-cleanup is not a standalone command anymore.

See I2119acd402b0985d4a81c85501ce7265f782d37b

Change-Id: I3421667916bf3652ab0e777fa78c382a3f6e849d

added_lines:
"POT-Creation-Date: 2016-09-29 02:18+0000
""PO-Revision-Date: 2016-09-28 02:46+0000
" "Last-Translator: Yuko Katabami <yukokatabami@gmail.com>
""Add a new setting OVERVIEW_DAYS_RANGE. It defines the default date range in " "the Overview panel meters - either today minus N days (if the value is " "integer N), or from the beginning of the current month until today (if set " "to None). This setting is be used to limit the amount of data fetched by " "default when rendering the Overview panel. The default value is 1, which " "differs from the past behaviour, since it caused serious lags on large " "deployments." msgstr "" "OVERVIEW_DAYS_RANGE の設定が新たに追加されました。これは、概要パネルのメー" "ターのデフォルト日付範囲を、今日の日付の N 日前までの範囲 (値が整数 N の場" "合)、または今月の始めから今日までの範囲 (None に設定されている場合) で定義し" "ます。この設定は、概要のパネルがレンダリングされる際に取得するデータの量を制" "限するために使用されます。デフォルト値は 1 です。以前は大型のデプロイメントで" "深刻なラグの原因となっていたため、以前のバージョンの動作とは異なるようになり" "ました。" msgid """Horizon currently supports both Angular 1.3.x and Angular 1.4.x, but will " "remove 1.3 support in the future. See `Migrating from 1.3 to 1.4 <https://" "docs.angularjs.org/guide/migration#migrating-from-1-3-to-1-4>`_" msgstr "" "Horizon は現在 Angular 1.3.x および Angular 1.4.x に対応していますが、今後は " "1.3 はサポートされなくなる予定です。「Migrating from 1.3 to 1.4 <https://" "docs.angularjs.org/guide/migration#migrating-from-1-3-to-1-4>」を参照してくだ" "さい。" msgid """If the 'default' theme is still required for legacy overrides to function, " "simply copy the styles in the 'default' theme into a pre-existing theme or " "create a new custom theme." msgstr "" "レガシーのオーバーライドが機能するために「default」テーマが依然として必要な場" "合には、単に「default」テーマのスタイルを以前から存在するテーマにコピーする" "か、新規カスタムテーマを作成してください。" msgid ""

commit_message:
zuul/layout/puppet: run scenario003 for puppet-designate

We added Designate support in scenario003 job. We would like to gate
puppet-designate on this job, now it works and it's stable.

Change-Id: Ib856cf005c0422bd241a8390af0c80b2fe915b8a

revisions:

(cherry picked from commit 69eaebc774c4f2132f6dc123ec296df7d3bd0cb0)

commit_message:
Delete Snapshot: status wrongly set when busy

This fix sets the snapshot status correctly to 'error_deleting',
when snapshot reported to be busy by backend driver.

Change-Id: Iecfd32b8265ce9f7cdfcba6d89397f269024b75d
Closes-Bug: #1564623
(cherry picked from commit 69eaebc774c4f2132f6dc123ec296df7d3bd0cb0)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/manila refs/changes/12/354812/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @ddt.data(exception.ShareSnapshotIsBusy(snapshot_name='fake_name'), exception.NotFound()) def test_delete_snapshot_driver_exception(self, exc): mock.Mock(side_effect=exc)) self.assertRaises(type(exc), self.share_manager.delete_snapshot,
deleted_lines: def test_delete_snapshot_driver_other_exception(self): def _raise_not_found(self, *args, **kwargs): raise exception.NotFound() mock.Mock(side_effect=_raise_not_found)) self.assertRaises(exception.NotFound, self.share_manager.delete_snapshot, def test_delete_snapshot_exception_snapshot_is_busy(self): """Test snapshot should not be deleted if busy.""" def _raise_share_snapshot_is_busy(self, *args, **kwargs): raise exception.ShareSnapshotIsBusy(snapshot_name='fakename') share_id = 'FAKE_SHARE_ID' share = fakes.fake_share( id=share_id, has_replicas=True, instance={'id': 'fake_id'}) snapshot_instance = fakes.fake_snapshot_instance( share_id=share_id, share=share, name='fake_snapshot') snapshot = fakes.fake_snapshot( share_id=share_id, share=share, instance=snapshot_instance, project_id=self.context.project_id) snapshot_id = snapshot['id'] self.mock_object(self.share_manager, '_get_share_server', mock.Mock(return_value=None)) self.mock_object(self.share_manager.db, 'share_snapshot_instance_get', mock.Mock(return_value=snapshot_instance)) self.mock_object(self.share_manager.db, 'share_snapshot_get', mock.Mock(return_value=snapshot)) self.mock_object(self.share_manager.driver, "delete_snapshot", mock.Mock(side_effect=_raise_share_snapshot_is_busy)) snapshot_update_call = self.mock_object( self.share_manager.db, 'share_snapshot_instance_update') self.mock_object( self.share_manager.db, 'share_get', mock.Mock(return_value=share)) self.assertRaises(exception.ShareSnapshotIsBusy, self.share_manager.delete_snapshot, self.context, snapshot_id) snapshot_update_call.assert_called_once_with( mock.ANY, snapshot_instance['id'], {'status': constants.STATUS_AVAILABLE})

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-29 09:46:59.000000000', 'files': ['debian/changelog', 'debian/patches/series', 'debian/patches/stores-SECRET_KEY-in-tmp-folder-for-tests.patch'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/deb-horizon/commit/7a5780bc83b631faa418d1605ead1aad13fb8cc1', 'message': "Use /tmp for SECRET_KEY

commit_message:
Use /tmp for SECRET_KEY

  * Add patch to use /tmp for the SECRET_KEY during tests, instead of the
    openstack_dashboard/test folder, which isn't suitable for plugins, and
    which would make them FTBFS.

Change-Id: Ia07dcfe65d94d910df38f1e5231a288f04fecb2e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/deb-horizon refs/changes/25/379325/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Description: Stores SECRET_KEY in /tmp for tests As horizon plugins are importing openstack_dashboard.test.settings, they attempt to write to /usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/openstack_dashboard/test which is read only. This patch should fix the problem. Author: Thomas Goirand <zigo@debian.org> Forwarded: not-needed Last-Update: 2016-09-29 --- horizon-10.0.0~rc2.orig/openstack_dashboard/test/settings.py +++ horizon-10.0.0~rc2/openstack_dashboard/test/settings.py @@ -34,7 +34,7 @@ STATIC_URL = '/static/' WEBROOT = '/' SECRET_KEY = secret_key.generate_or_read_from_file( - os.path.join(TEST_DIR, '.secret_key_store')) + os.path.join('/tmp', '.secret_key_store')) ROOT_URLCONF = 'openstack_dashboard.test.urls' TEMPLATES[0]['DIRS'] = [

Remove packaging directory

This is to reduce duplication and syncing efforts.  The packaging configuration
will now only be kept in the RDO tripleo-ui-distgit repository.

DeploymentDetail component

* Add deployment detail logic for displaying relevant information
  depending on the state of deployment
* Add Deployment confirmation/summary page

Change-Id: I378a6a731af60b64c7eed60082a96b32bfa87434
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ui refs/changes/89/376189/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import { connect } from 'react-redux'; import ImmutablePropTypes from 'react-immutable-proptypes'; import React from 'react'; import DeploymentConfirmation from './DeploymentConfirmation'; import { getCurrentPlan } from '../../selectors/plans'; import { getCurrentStack } from '../../selectors/stacks'; import { getPreDeploymentValidationsStatusCounts } from '../../selectors/validations'; import PlanActions from '../../actions/PlansActions'; class DeploymentDetail extends React.Component { render() { if (!this.props.currentStack) { return ( <DeploymentConfirmation currentPlan={this.props.currentPlan} deployPlan={this.props.deployPlan} validationsCounts={this.props.validationsCounts}/> ); } else if (this.props.currentStack.stack_status.match(/PROGRESS/)) { return ( null ); } else if (this.props.currentStack.stack_status.match(/SUCCESS/)) { return ( // DeploymentSuccess null ); } else { return ( // DeploymentFailure null ); } } } const mapStateToProps = (state) => { return { currentPlan: getCurrentPlan(state), currentStack: getCurrentStack(state), validationsCounts: getPreDeploymentValidationsStatusCounts(state) }; }; const mapDispatchToProps = (dispatch) => { return { deployPlan: planName => dispatch(PlanActions.deployPlan(planName)) }; }; DeploymentDetail.propTypes = { currentPlan: ImmutablePropTypes.record.isRequired, currentStack: ImmutablePropTypes.record, deployPlan: React.PropTypes.func.isRequired, validationsCounts: React.PropTypes.object.isRequired }; export default connect(mapStateToProps, mapDispatchToProps)(DeploymentDetail);

commit_message:
Move db::mysql into service_config_settings

This patch movs the various db::mysql hiera settings into a
'mysql' specific service_config_settings section for each
service so that these will only get applied on the MySQL service
node. This follows a similar puppet-tripleo change where we
create the actual databases for all services locally on
the MySQL service node to avoid permission issues.

Change-Id: Ic0692b1f7aa8409699630ef3924c4be98ca6ffb2
Closes-bug: #1620595
Depends-On: I05cc0afa9373429a3197c194c3e8f784ae96de5f
Depends-On: I5e1ef2dc6de6f67d7c509e299855baec371f614d

commit_message:
Fuelclient version 10 handled

In python-fuelclient >= 10 APIClient was renamed to DefaultAPIClient
Number of saving items decreased in the
test_get_resource_values_effective_lot_of_data
for fix test timeout error on the CI servers.

Change-Id: Icdad2f7acfc6a05684bb2d9e8f73d18a252f20e6

used to mean JSON four times. This patch revises json to JSON.

commit_message:
Release Mistral Newton RC3

Sorry for the frequent RC release application. A critical security
related bug was found in Mistral master and was fixed today. So request
another urgent release after backport.

Change-Id: I77e9f40cc38cdb18e733ba299078f00e283368ba

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/89/379189/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: New, updated, and deprecated options in Newton for Identity service
deleted_lines: New, updated, and deprecated options in Mitaka for Identity service.. list-table:: New options :header-rows: 1 :class: config-ref-table * - Option = default value - (Type) Help string * - ``[DEFAULT] insecure_debug = False`` - (BoolOpt) If set to true the server will return information in the response that may allow an unauthenticated or authenticated user to get more information than normal, such as why authentication failed. This may be useful for debugging but is insecure. * - ``[DEFAULT] notification_opt_out = []`` - (MultiStrOpt) Define the notification options to opt-out from. The value expected is: identity.<resource_type>.<operation>. This field can be set multiple times in order to add more notifications to opt-out from. For example: notification_opt_out=identity.user.created notification_opt_out=identity.authenticate.success * - ``[assignment] prohibited_implied_role = admin`` - (ListOpt) A list of role names which are prohibited from being an implied role. * - ``[ldap] group_members_are_ids = False`` - (BoolOpt) If the members of the group objectclass are user IDs rather than DNs, set this to true. This is the case when using posixGroup as the group objectclass and OpenDirectory. * - ``[ldap] user_description_attribute = description`` - (StrOpt) LDAP attribute mapped to user description. * - ``[resource] admin_project_domain_name = None`` - (StrOpt) Name of the domain that owns the `admin_project_name`. Defaults to None. * - ``[resource] admin_project_name = None`` - (StrOpt) Special project for performing administrative operations on remote services. Tokens scoped to this project will contain the key/value `is_admin_project=true`. Defaults to None. * - ``[resource] domain_name_url_safe = off`` - (StrOpt) Whether the names of domains are restricted from containing url reserved characters. If set to new, attempts to create or update a domain with a url unsafe name will return an error. In addition, if set to strict, attempts to scope a token using a domain name which is unsafe will return an error. * - ``[resource] project_name_url_safe = off`` - (StrOpt) Whether the names of projects are restricted from containing url reserved characters. If set to new, attempts to create or update a project with a url unsafe name will return an error. In addition, if set to strict, attempts to scope a token using an unsafe project name will return an error. * - ``[shadow_users] driver = sql`` - (StrOpt) Entrypoint for the shadow users backend driver in the keystone.identity.shadow_users namespace. * - ``[token] infer_roles = True`` - (BoolOpt) Add roles to token that are not explicitly added, but that are linked implicitly to other roles. .. list-table:: New default values :header-rows: 1 :class: config-ref-table * - Option - Previous default value - New default value * - ``[DEFAULT] admin_token`` - ``ADMIN`` - ``None`` * - ``[DEFAULT] secure_proxy_ssl_header`` - ``None`` - ``HTTP_X_FORWARDED_PROTO`` * - ``[cache] backend`` - ``keystone.common.cache.noop`` - ``dogpile.cache.null`` * - ``[cache] config_prefix`` - ``cache.keystone`` - ``cache.oslo`` * - ``[ldap] use_auth_pool`` - ``False`` - ``True`` * - ``[ldap] use_pool`` - ``False`` - ``True`` * - ``[os_inherit] enabled`` - ``False`` - ``True``

commit_message:
Set the valid choices for the rabbit login methods

According to the RabbitMQ client docs [1], the only valid login
methods are: PLAIN, AMQPLAIN, or RABBIT-CR-DEMO. This patch restricts
the rabbit driver to only those options.

[1] https://www.rabbitmq.com/authentication.html

Change-Id: I193f33adf4ecc1c0fd29ddc08b35533f24f1c967
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging refs/changes/10/372810/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Ubuntu mariadb install no longer prompts for pass

Installing Newton RC on Ubuntu 16.04,

apt-get install mariadb-server python-pymysql

no longer results in a prompt to set the root password,
bringing it into line with other distributions.

The install guide contains a reference to the previous behaviour

"Choose a suitable password for the database root account."

which is no longer necessary, and as such this patch removes it.

Change-Id: I46e8e02d7de00b08dff4648fe51a1da10bd053b9

commit_message:
Improve help text for glance options

The previous commit moved the glance options to a
central location. This commit adds additional help text to
those options.

Checked consistency and removed the tags according to wiki:
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ConfigOptionsConsistency

Blueprint centralize-config-options-ocata

Change-Id: I24abf345271f6d457a5c57d564440517ce498a55

commit_message:
Octavia: Basic LoadBalancer Scenario Test

TESTING: Devstack plugin changes to run scenarios

Adds: Structure for tempest testing
Adds: Required tempest files and configuration for tempest testing
Adds: Octavia clients for communication with the API
Adds: Utilities for tempest testing
Adds: Mock session in method test_update_health_no_status_change of test_update_db

Co-Authored-By: Franklin Naval <franklin.naval@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: Madhusudhan Kandadai <madhusudhan.openstack@gmail.com>
Co-Authored-By: min wang <swiftwangster@gmail.com>

Change-Id: Ifd821ad0d94131e7dc42f2a52746ec094cf4153e

commit_message:
Add 'How plugins work' section from Wiki

Change-Id: Iea1e6d0f2d9f5800aecd1643052b35816b2757be
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-docs refs/changes/14/367314/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Beginning with version 6.0, Fuel features the ability to install plugins along with your environment. Fuel plugins are downloadable software components that enable you to add new capabilities to your environments in a flexible, repeatable and reliable manner. There is no need to install drivers and patches manually after Fuel deploys your cloud – plugins do this for you. Fuel plugins enable you to install and configure additional capabilities fo r your cloud, such as additional storage types and networking functionality. For example, a `Load Balancing as a Service (LBaaS) <https://github.com/openstack/fuel-plugin-neutron-lbaas>`_ plugin allows you to add network load balancing functionality to your cloud so that incoming traffic can be spread across multiple nodes. Or you might want to use a `Nova NFS plugin <https://github.com/openstack/fuel-plugin-nova-nfs>`_ so that you can use `NFS <https://ru.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_File_System>`_ as a storage backend for Nova ephemeral volumes. Fuel offers an open source framework for creating these plugins, so there’s a wide range of capabilities that you can enable Fuel to add to your OpenStack clouds. If you’re a hardware vendor that has created drivers that enable OpenStack to work with your product, you can create a plugin so Fuel can deploy those drivers when it’s standing up new clouds. Or you might simply want to enable OpenStack functionality that’s not readily available in Fuel. Because Fuel includes a pluggable framework, you’re not limited to what’s provided “out of the box”. You are also free to use `DriverLog <http://stackalytics.com/report/driverlog?project_id=openstack/fuel>`_ as the single registry for all Fuel Plugins.

commit_message:
Change assertTrue(isinstance()) by optimal assert

Some of tests use different method of assertTrue(isinstance(A, B))
or assertEqual(type(A), B).
The correct way is to use assertIsInstance(A, B) provided by testtools

Change-Id: I15ff9fdab8cdf098634a48879e8992a59bfa91b2

commit_message:
Plugins SDK: reference for deployment_tasks.yaml

Change-Id: Ief5fdb64cce8b3ed9367157e04e06d8a5083199d
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-docs refs/changes/19/369719/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ===================== The file ``deployment_tasks.yaml`` is used to define deployment tasks and dependencies between them. Example: .. code-block:: ini - id: myplugin-keystonedb groups: [primary-controller] required_for: [keystone] requires: [database] type: puppet parameters: puppet_manifest: /etc/puppet/modules/osnailyfacter/modular/keystone/db.pp puppet_modules: /etc/puppet/modules timeout: 1800 Fields: ``role`` Describes a role of a node where tasks will be executed. Should only be used with pre/post deployment tasks. ``groups`` Describes a group of nodes with the specified role where tasks will be executed and should only be used with the main deployment tasks. The task must have either a 'role' or 'group' field, but not both of them at the same time. ``requires`` Specifies the list of tasks needed by the current one. The list of tasks can be obtained by running the command: .. code-block:: console fuel graph --env 1 --download ``required_for`` Specifies the list of tasks for which the current one is needed. ``timeout`` Specifies the execution timeout in seconds. Once it is specified, the deployment will fail if the timeout expires. By default, the timeout is set to 300 seconds. ``type`` Determines a type of the task, should be one of 'shell', 'puppet', 'reboot' or 'group'. ``type: shell`` Task with the type 'shell' will run shell script defined in the parameter 'cmd'. Example: .. code-block:: ini # This tasks will be applied on controller nodes, # here you can also specify several roles, for example # ['cinder', 'compute'] will be applied only on # cinder and compute nodes - id: task-shell-deploy role: ['controller'] type: shell parameters: cmd: bash deploy.sh timeout: 42 - id: task-shell-deploy role: ['cinder','compute''] type: shell parameters: cmd: bash deploy.sh timeout: 42 # Task is applied for all roles - id: task-shell-pluginlog role: '*' type: shell parameters: cmd: echo all > /tmp/plugin.all timeout: 42 ``type: puppet`` Task with the type 'puppet' allows you to apply your own Puppet manifests on OpenStack nodes. Parameters: * puppet_manifest - manifests directory path (relative to deployment_scripts). * puppet_modules - modules directory path (relative to deployment_scripts). Example: .. code-block:: ini # Deployment will be applied on controllers only - role: ['controller'] type: puppet parameters: puppet_manifest: puppet/manifests/site.pp puppet_modules: puppet/modules timeout: 360 ``type: reboot`` Task with the type 'reboot' allows you to reboot nodes with the specified roles after the timeout. Example: .. code-block:: ini - role: '*' type: reboot parameters: timeout: 300 ``type: group`` Task with the type 'group' is actually a meta-task. It should contain the field 'tasks' with the llst of tasks to be executed on the specified nodes. .. code-block:: ini - id: standalone-keystone type: group role: [standalone-keystone] requires: [deploy_start, primary-standalone-keystone] required_for: [deploy_end] tasks: [fuel_pkgs, hiera, globals, tools, logging, netconfig, hosts, firewall, deploy_start, cluster, keystone-vip, cluster-haproxy, memcached, openstack-haproxy-stats, task-keystone] parameters: strategy: type: parallel When you set up a group of tasks you can also specify how they will be executed: in “parallel” or “one-by-one”. ``strategy: type`` * "parallel" - tasks will be executed in parallel * "one-by-one" - tasks will be executed one-by-one Once you choose “parallel” you can specify the maximal number of tasks that can be run in parallel using the “amount” parameter. .. code-block:: ini - id: controller type: group role: [controller] requires: [primary-controller] required_for: [deploy_end] parameters: strategy: type: parallel amount: 6

commit_message:
Implement receiver notification handling

This patch implements receiver notification handling:
Senlin engine will claim messages from Zaqar service once
message notification is received. Actions will be built
and fired for each message which has valid cluster
identity and action specified. Invalid message will be
ignored.

Change-Id: I2a82af197b2ec3bfa1265a777f6b20fd6635c4e6
Partial-bp: message-based-receiver

commit_message:
Add tests for API microversion 2.26 (instance tags)

Added tempest tests for server tags in nova-api.

Co-Authored-By: Sergey Nikitin <snikitin@mirantis.com>

Change-Id: I55ed7c0392e3885fc58099b907b2299bb5779077
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/76/233176/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2015 Mirantis Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from tempest.api.compute import base from tempest import test class ServerTagsTestJSON(base.BaseV2ComputeTest): @classmethod def setup_clients(cls): super(ServerTagsTestJSON, cls).setup_clients() cls.client = cls.servers_client @classmethod def resource_setup(cls): super(ServerTagsTestJSON, cls).resource_setup() server = cls.create_test_server(wait_until='ACTIVE') cls.server_id = server['id'] """ def setUp(self): super(ServerTagsTestJSON, self).setUp() tags = ['test'] self.client.set_instance_tags(self.server_id, tags)['tags'] """ @test.idempotent_id('e477e83a-6dbd-11e5-9d70-feff819cdc9f') def test_list_server_tags(self): resp_tags = (self.client.list_instance_tags(self.server_id)['tags']) expected = [] self.assertEqual(expected, resp_tags)

commit_message:
Add keystone.CreateAndGetRole

Create a user role and get it detailed information.

Change-Id: I7e68dcb21217116e328cdcffbfc1452f135acfe6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/18/379218/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_create_and_get_role(self): scenario = basic.CreateAndGetRole(self.context) fake_role = mock.MagicMock() scenario._role_create = mock.MagicMock(return_value=fake_role) scenario._get_role = mock.MagicMock() scenario.run() scenario._role_create.assert_called_once_with() scenario._get_role.assert_called_once_with(fake_role.id)

Change-Id: I56e955bd1925f9280e2c54957b4c8a6b50e1bcc5
'}]
commit_message:
[vCenter] Minor fixes for vCenter suite

* Increase timeout for creation instances
* Fix DVS parameters for scale tests
* CERT_BYBASS value should be boolean
* PROGRESS_TO_STOP value should be integer

Change-Id: I56e955bd1925f9280e2c54957b4c8a6b50e1bcc5

commit_message:
Translate log messages

The Log "LOG.info(_LI(...)" is used in some places,but the log
"LOG.info(_(..))" still used in a few places.

Change-Id: I308a4a97938b46338f98b42805799fd97206341d

subject: Backup nova to local
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-05-12 13:11:04.000000000', 'files': ['freezer/openstack/backup.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/freezer/commit/7243e741ddcb5bea6b899fe3861593666a18bd29', 'message': 'Backup nova to local

Now, freezer-agent backup nova to swift by default.
but more and more demand  backup it to the specified directory.
This patch fix it backup it to local.

backup nova usage:
freezer-agent --nova-inst-id 1983bb28-b962-4597-ab83-c7529594c1c5
--storage local --container /home/nfs

restore nova usage:

freezer-agent --nova-inst-id 1983bb28-b962-4597-ab83-c7529594c1c5
--restore-from-date 2016-04-28T09:55:50 --storage local
--container /home/nfs

Closes-Bug: #1576008
Implements blueprint: backup-nova-cinder-to-non-swift

Change-Id: I1e7e889e76b655465ffa1a1dd99d0ec66e2dcf0d
'}]
commit_message:
Backup nova to local

Now, freezer-agent backup nova to swift by default.
but more and more demand  backup it to the specified directory.
This patch fix it backup it to local.

backup nova usage:
freezer-agent --nova-inst-id 1983bb28-b962-4597-ab83-c7529594c1c5
--storage local --container /home/nfs

restore nova usage:

freezer-agent --nova-inst-id 1983bb28-b962-4597-ab83-c7529594c1c5
--restore-from-date 2016-04-28T09:55:50 --storage local
--container /home/nfs

Closes-Bug: #1576008
Implements blueprint: backup-nova-cinder-to-non-swift

Change-Id: I1e7e889e76b655465ffa1a1dd99d0ec66e2dcf0d

commit_message:
backup cinder_by_glance to local

Freezer-agent backup volume_by_glance upload data to swift by default.
This patch backup it and metadata to local,Now.

usage:
backup:
freezer-agent --cinder-vol-id 0bd0d291-e75c-4fd9-b13b-058c335a8497
--storage local --containder /home/nfs

restore:

freezer-agent --action restore
--cinder-vol-id 0bd0d291-e75c-4fd9-b13b-058c335a8497
--storage local --container /home/nfs
--restore-from-date 2016-05-10T00:01:00

Closes-Bug: #1580415

Change-Id: I926ab3e7285d55b543b93d372afe35b3c74952a2
Implements blueprint: backup-nova-cinder-to-non-swift
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/freezer refs/changes/85/315085/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import osimport json def __init__(self, client_manager, container, storage=None, backup_storage=None): self.storage = storage self.backup_storage = backup_storage container = self.container.rstrip("/") if self.backup_storage == 'swift': swift = self.client_manager.get_swift() backup = self._get_backups(path, restore_from_timestamp) stream = swift.get_object( self.container, "%s/%s" % (path, backup), resp_chunk_size=10000000) length = int(stream[0]["x-object-meta-length"]) logging.info("[*] Creation glance image") image = glance.images.create( data=utils.ReSizeStream(stream[1], length, 1), container_format="bare", disk_format="raw") return stream[0], image #elif self.backup_storage == 'local': else: image_dir = "{0}/{1}".format(container, path) # if not image_dir: # msg = "Cannot find backups for path: %s" % image_dir # logging.error(msg) if image_dir: # list backup dir backuplist = [int(x) for x in os.listdir(image_dir) if x.isdigit()] # list backup file available get_restore_timestamp = [x for x in backuplist if x >= restore_from_timestamp] if not get_restore_timestamp: backupdir = max(backuplist) else: backupdir = min(get_restore_timestamp) image_dir = "{0}/{1}/{2}".format(container, path, backupdir) image_file = "{0}/{1}".format(image_dir, path) metadata_file = "%s-meta" % image_file #import pdb;pdb.set_trace() with open(image_file) as backup_file: image = glance.images.create( data=backup_file, container_format="bare", disk_format="raw", name=backupdir) metadata = json.load(file(metadata_file)) return metadata, image if not image_dir: msg = "Cannot find backups for path: %s" % image_dir logging.error(msg) if self.backup_storage == 'swift': length = int(info["x-object-meta-length"]) gb = 1073741824 size = length / gb if length % gb > 0: size += 1 else : size = int(info["volume-size"])

commit_message:
Fix sample config generation for cinder, nova and neutron opts

While generating a sample config with "tox -egenconfig", some options
for the Nova, Cinder and Neutron client are not added to the [nova],
[cinder] and [neutron] section. I.e. "api_insecure" is not available for
all sections. Register the config options under the correct group while
generating the sample config.

Closes-Bug: #1613303
Change-Id: If54fd42f7a06c159bcb6df5f684dc1211a9b91e9
(cherry picked from commit 5c95e5cc10e0798d191ea33af8cc43fce2a6ae19)

commit_message:
Add doc about cloud_backend

This adds some docs about the 'cloud_backend' configuration option.

Change-Id: I3cbfa1c4c6037a4283507c2e83d94d564a2c52a2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/94/379094/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Cloud Backends ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ The senlin server is shipped with two collections of "cloud backends": one for interacting with a real OpenStack deployment, the other for running complex tests including api tests, functional tests, stress tests. The first cloud backend is referred to as '`openstack`' and the second is referred to as '`openstack_test`'. While the `openstack` cloud backend contains full featured drivers for senlin to talk to the OpenStack services supported, the `openstack_test` backend contains some "dummy" drivers that return fake responses for service requests. The `openstack_test` driver is located at :file:`senlin/tests/drivers` subdirectory. It is provided to facilitate tests on the senlin service itself without involving any other OpenStack services. Several types of tests can benefit from these "dummy" drivers because 1) they can save developers a lot time on debugging complex issues when interacting with other OpenStack services, and 2) they make running those types of tests much easier and quicker. Note that "Integration Tests" are designed for senlin to interact with real services so we should use the `openstack` backend rather than the `openstack_test` backend. To configure the backend to use before running tests, you can check the `[DEFAULT]` section in the configuration file :file:`/etc/senlin/senlin.conf`. :: [DEFAULT] cloud_backend = openstack_test # use this for api, functional tests; # or 'openstack' for production environment # and integration tests.

commit_message:
Clear the old environment in rc file

When sourcing the Keystone RC file, some of the variable options are
conflicting, and may provide the wrong information to a token request.
For example, If both OS_USERNAME and OS_USER_ID are passed, the
Keystone Client has to chose which one to add to the token request,
and it might not be the one the user expects.  The same is true for
any value that can be passed both by name and ID. In addition, some
of the combinations lead to cryptic error messages.

To clearly identify the users intention, the old environment is
cleared of all variables that start with the `OS_` prefix
before setting any new variables.

Change-Id: I6badc5864426a371323a59100155e1c284af84b8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient refs/changes/53/347553/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: f.write("# Clear any old environment that may conflict.\n" ) f.write("for key in `set | grep -E '^OS_'` ; do unset $key ; done\n" )

commit_message:
Merge tag '3.0.0_rc1' into debian/newton

Tagger: OpenStack Release Bot <infra-root@openstack.org>
Date:   Thu Sep 15 18:25:09 2016 +0000

retag 3.0.0_rc1 of murano-dashboard 3.0.0.0rc1 release candidate

  * New upstream release.
  * Fixed (build-)depends for this release.
  * Using OpenStack Gerrit as VCS URLs:
    - Point .gitreview to packaging-deb project.
    - Add .gitreview in extend-diff-ignore.
  * Fix source path for copying the _50_murano.py enabling script.

Change-Id: Iec451f5160617e34c6de29f8fe249da3270cf202

commit_message:
Small refactoring translation mechanism

1. Currently translation rule raises property conflict exception,
   if there's some conflict. Error doesn't contain path, where it
   has been raised, so need to handle this case.

2. If properties data has list of dicts, from which some key should
   be deleted, delete rule raises KeyError if there's no key. Need to
   handle that case.

Change-Id: I77b1ed72db51a5bd292fb1ccbe5a06f5f06a5a8c

commit_message:
Add network gateway validation

Check whether the gateway defined in `undercloud.conf` exists and is
reachable.

This validation demonstrates how to use the hiera facter to get the
path to undercloud.conf file.

Change-Id: I23f520baf0d787807ba7275c1b2e69a1a671529d
Co-Authored-By: Tomas Sedovic <tsedovic@redhat.com>
Depends-On: I78cdd1b9844a12ef43fee3d5967d00a7d9992b02
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-validations refs/changes/85/329385/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env python import subprocess from ansible.module_utils.basic import * def main(): module = AnsibleModule(argument_spec=dict( name=dict(required=True, type='str'), )) name = module.params.get('name') cmd = ['/usr/bin/hiera', name] result = subprocess.check_output(cmd).rstrip() if result == 'nil': module.fail_json(msg="Failed to retrieve hiera data for {}".format(name)) module.exit_json(changed=False, ansible_facts={name: result}) if __name__ == '__main__': main()

commit_message:
Skip assigning address assigned as dynamic

This is a less invasive fix than the patch at
I8684370ff1ad9387d0e2f450ce483b22b613a3c7 but
it is more hacky because its just skipping
the dynamic address from an RA rather than
preventing it from being assigned in the first
place.

It may be safer to merge this for RC2 than the
other one.

commit_message:
Drop the deprecation function from_primitive.

As it's annotation says: This should go away in early O as we stop supporting
backward compatibility with M,and now,we are already in early Ocata,So,we can
abandon it.

Change-Id: Iceec75bba88cc89318d23ebdc3de948dc69ef5ef

deleted_lines: from cinder import objects @classmethod def from_primitives(cls, spec): """Returns RequestSpec object creating it from legacy dictionary. FIXME(dulek): This should go away in early O as we stop supporting backward compatibility with M. """ spec = spec.copy() spec_obj = cls() vol_props = spec.pop('volume_properties', {}) if vol_props is not None: vol_props = VolumeProperties(**vol_props) spec_obj.volume_properties = vol_props if 'volume' in spec: vol = spec.pop('volume', {}) vol.pop('name', None) if vol is not None: vol = objects.Volume(**vol) spec_obj.volume = vol if 'volume_type' in spec: vol_type = spec.pop('volume_type', {}) if vol_type is not None: vol_type = objects.VolumeType(**vol_type) spec_obj.volume_type = vol_type spec.pop('resource_properties', None) for k, v in spec.items(): setattr(spec_obj, k, v) return spec_obj

commit_message:
Add error message, when run not on a tty

The library, which displays user interface, urwid,
executes ioctl on stdin file descriptor, which
works only on ttys. Let's report error, when we run
not on a tty to make error investigation easier.

Change-Id: I15e80f14f65f6467eca153dc2cd73c64751c9154
Partial-Bug: #1607402

commit_message:
Clean imports in code

This patch set modifies lines which are importing objects
instead of modules. As per openstack import guide lines, user should
import modules in a file not objects.

http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/#imports

Change-Id: I62e9a6d895685c07ec87a5cc910c5036e05b4906

commit_message:
Preparing multinode networking for Ironic

At the gates Ironic uses VMs instead of real hardware servers.
Those VMs are not managed by Nova and is used for emulating hardware
servers for Ironic. In multinode topology those VMs are created on
all nodes primary and subnodes. This patch adds an extra vxlan tunnel
and new bridge br_ironic_vxlan to provide connectivity between VMs on
different nodes.

Change-Id: I8892a2418e3bee35dacce1d5959faa30dd38e971

commit_message:
Include entity in provisioning block logs

Update debug log message to include the entity that triggered
provisioning complete. The entity is included on other debug
log messages and is helpful in debugging provisioning problems.

Change-Id: Ic14a3ae3a4b5262d383a3ad8f0cc341f0705bd0e

subject: [Scenarios] WIP! Improve some neutron scenarios
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-04-14 15:35:07.000000000', 'files': ['tests/unit/plugins/openstack/scenarios/neutron/test_network.py', 'rally/plugins/openstack/scenarios/neutron/utils.py', 'tests/unit/plugins/openstack/scenarios/neutron/test_utils.py', 'rally/plugins/openstack/scenarios/neutron/network.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/rally/commit/a7f1d518acb5ab8f6cdde30c1364d441c12d7413', 'message': '[Scenarios] WIP! Improve some neutron scenarios

This changes the following scenarios:

  * NeutronNetworks.create_and_list_ports
     - bulk ports creation (single atomic action)
  * NeutronNetworks.create_and_update_ports
     - bulk ports creation (single atomic action)
     - bulk ports updating (single atomic action)
     - create all ports for given network and then update
       all these ports, instead of create-and-update action
       for each port
  * NeutronNetworks.create_and_delete_ports
     - bulk ports creation (single atomic action)
     - bulk ports deletion (single atomic action)
     - create all ports for given network and then delete
       all these ports, instead of create-and-delete action
       for each port

For bulk actions, the following methods are added to utils:

  * Neutron_scenario._create_ports
  * Neutron_scenario._update_ports
  * Neutron_scenario._delete_ports

Change-Id: I44fe8ee36e044db12b1349b2cb0c8b2b233b39d1

commit_message:
[Scenarios] WIP! Improve some neutron scenarios

This changes the following scenarios:

  * NeutronNetworks.create_and_list_ports
     - bulk ports creation (single atomic action)
  * NeutronNetworks.create_and_update_ports
     - bulk ports creation (single atomic action)
     - bulk ports updating (single atomic action)
     - create all ports for given network and then update
       all these ports, instead of create-and-update action
       for each port
  * NeutronNetworks.create_and_delete_ports
     - bulk ports creation (single atomic action)
     - bulk ports deletion (single atomic action)
     - create all ports for given network and then delete
       all these ports, instead of create-and-delete action
       for each port

For bulk actions, the following methods are added to utils:

  * Neutron_scenario._create_ports
  * Neutron_scenario._update_ports
  * Neutron_scenario._delete_ports

Change-Id: I44fe8ee36e044db12b1349b2cb0c8b2b233b39d1

commit_message:
Fix dict and set order related issues in tests

There are several tests where the expected output
relies on order of strings generated from the arbitrary
ordering of dictionaries or sets. The new version of
tox causes that ordering to be different between tests
runs so tests must be resilient and test either the
content of the dicts or sets or their sorted output.

Note: These fixes are only of those cases where a failure
was generated. If there are issues in skipped tests, this
patch has not found nor fixed them. The vast majority of
skipped tests are related to availability of functionality
so there's little that can be done about that with the
current testing setup. The best we can do is be on the
lookout for failures that could be related PYTHONHASHSEED
down the road and fix them as they happen.

Closes-Bug: 1348818
Change-Id: I6b27ca2597c51b0656f441f325f9ffd0e31a606d

commit_message:
Behavioral fixes to Magic-Search

Issues fixed:
* Fixes issue where text entry is borked when clicking to make a new facet
* No ‘x’ icon when text search only
* Text search, then click “x”, text search NOT removed and search result not updated
* Text search, then click facet, text hidden but still used
* Text search, then select a facet, hit main “x”, only facet removed, text search
  NOT removed
* text search, enter to make text facet, then “x”, then select a “Type” “Image” facet,
  then the text facet reappears, then “x” again and Image facet cleared but text facet
  remains

Change-Id: I3f00836684fade0f1050d180a44924af48e3d868
Closes-Bug: 1628588

commit_message:
Remove Routes from requirements

This was introduced in the very first commit for requirments (change
Ib62c6ab685c1bcf14ed363031010c4a145098df6) with comment:
"Needed by oslo.common" - with the end of oslo-incubator this is not
valid anymore. No code currently in tree uses "routes", so remove the
requirement.

Change-Id: I952f7e765bdb642f2e12758558498166322e3861

commit_message:
Drop duplicated exception handle code from docker driver

Currently in container creation workflow, both compute manager[1]
and compute driver[2] has logic to handle docker APIError.

Actually we only need the logic in compute manager and the logic
in compute driver shall be dropped.

[1]https://github.com/openstack/zun/blob/master/zun/compute/manager.py#L83
[2]https://github.com/openstack/zun/blob/master/zun/container/docker/driver.py#L71

Change-Id: Ie2decd12f45bb8a0774f4ccbaac0dfd306ebb62b
Closes-bug: #1627653

Fix Container details styles

details are being displayed as a bulleted list which is wrong
this patch fixes that.

commit_message:
Fixed serial console not appearing in horizon

The lib file term.js has been moved into a subfolder 'termjs'.
So the link path of this file should be updated too.

Change-Id: I022c84e4e5bf7935db157af40a306a477291e36a
Closes-Bug: #1623799

commit_message:
Fix some fuzzy descriptions in the installation.rst

1. What is the problem?
In the original spec, there are some fuzzy descriptions:
 * Before we run the commands to test some functions in the Tricircle,
   we need to import the environment variables. So it is necessary to
   describe this file "admin-openrc.sh" more clearly before test.
 * When creating pod instances for Tricircle and bottom OpenStack,
   this document lack the instructions for the parameter "token".
 * Some volume actions tests lacked in this document.

2. What is the solution to the problem?
We add some descriptions about environment variables and parameter
"token". We also add some volume actions tests in this document.

3. What the features need to be implemented to the Tricircle to
realize the solution?
None

Change-Id: Id8439415548a4366b0d4e0cfbf3886e5f1ee5bb9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tricircle refs/changes/14/372414/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - 4 After DevStack successfully starts, we need to create environment variables for the admin user. In DevStack folder, create a file admin-openrc, and copy the content of https://github.com/openstack/tricircle/blob/master/devstack/admin-openrc.sh to the adminrc, change the password in the file if needed. Then run the following command to set the environment variables:: source admin-openrc 'admin-openrc.sh' is used to create environment variable as the following:: export OS_PROJECT_DOMAIN_ID=default export OS_USER_DOMAIN_ID=default export OS_PROJECT_NAME=admin export OS_TENANT_NAME=admin export OS_USERNAME=admin export OS_PASSWORD=password #change password as you set in your own environment export OS_AUTH_URL=http://127.0.0.1:5000 export OS_IDENTITY_API_VERSION=3 export OS_IMAGE_API_VERSION=2 export OS_REGION_NAME=RegionOne - 5 Check if services have been correctly registered. Run "openstack endpoint list" and you should get output look like as following:: instance. The two "token" ids can obtain from the Keystone of RegionOne and Pod1. We can use two commands to get the two "token" ids as following:: openstack token issue openstack --os-region-name Pod1 token issue The Tricircle API service will automatically create an aggregate when user creates a bottom pod, so command "nova aggregate-list" will show neutron net-list- 10 Attach the volume to a server:: cinder create --availability-zone=az1 1 cinder list nova list nova volume-attach $vm_id $volume_id cinder volume show $volume_id HOST_IP=10.250.201.24All the following operations are performed in node1. - 1 After the setup is finished, we also need to create environment variables for the admin user. In DevStack folder, create a file admin-openrc, and copy the content of https://github.com/openstack/tricircle/blob/master/devstack/admin-openrc.sh to the adminrc, change the password in the file if needed. Then run the following command to set the environment variables:: source admin-openrc - 2 Check if services have been correctly registered. Run "openstack endpoint- 3 Create pod instances for Tricircle and bottom OpenStack, the two "token" ids can be obtained from the Keystone of RegionOne, Pod1 and Pod2::- 4 Create network with AZ scheduler hints specified, the two "token" ids can be obtained from the Keystone of RegionOne, Pod1 and Pod2:: Here we create two networks separately bound to Pod1 and Pod2. - 5 Create necessary resources to boot virtual machines:: neutron net-list- 6 Boot virtual machines::- 7 Create router and attach interface::- 8 Launch VNC console anc check connectivityfound in devstack/ directory. And a demo blog with virtualbox can be found in https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Play_tricircle_with_virtualbox
deleted_lines: - 4 In DevStack folder, create a file adminrc, and copy the content of https://github.com/openstack/tricircle/blob/master/devstack/admin-openrc.sh to the adminrc, change the password in the file if needed. And run the following command to set the environment variables:: source adminrc - 5 After DevStack successfully starts, check if services have been correctly registered. Run "openstack endpoint list" and you should get output look like as following:: instance. The Tricircle API service will automatically create an aggregate when user creates a bottom pod, so command "nova aggregate-list" will show HOST_IP=10.250.201.24All the following operations are performed in node1 - 1 Check if services have been correctly registered. Run "openstack endpoint- 2 Create pod instances for Tricircle and bottom OpenStack::- 3 Create network with AZ scheduler hints specified:: Here we create two networks separately bound to Pod1 and Pod2 - 4 Create necessary resources to boot virtual machines::- 5 Boot virtual machines::- 6 Create router and attach interface::- 7 Launch VNC console anc check connectivityfound in devstack/ directory. And a demo blog with virtualbox can be found in https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Play_tricircle_with_virtualbox

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary setUp

setUp will be automatically called around each testcase,
so this is to remove setUp that doing nothing additional
than super to keep code clean.

Change-Id: I0c05c1df2607160368deb93b1b98b05ad0884140

commit_message:
Add Apache 2.0 license to source file

As per OpenStack licensing guide lines [1]:
[H102 H103] Newly contributed Source Code should be licensed under
the Apache 2.0 license.
[H104] Files with no code shouldn't contain any license header nor
comments, and must be left completely empty.

[1] http://docs.openstack.org/developer/hacking/#openstack-licensing

Change-Id: I3c3b43af534dbfd0a0b4854265a42999c14c53b8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/magnum-ui refs/changes/24/378224/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Implement libvirt-based driver for virtual HW

Libvirt is a mature virtualization abstraction layer,
with stable Python API, and is already used at the core of OpenStack.
Ironic testing on virtual hardware might benefit
from its adoption as well.

Change-Id: Ib3e8b41202f56ea1f5efd83b28932eb8edcbbbc3
Related-Bug: #1523880
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-specs refs/changes/21/254421/7 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =================================================== Implement libvirt-based Power and Management driver =================================================== Libvirt_ is a mature virtualization abstraction library that supports many technologies using a unified interface, has a solid Python API and is quite flexible in respect of transport used for connection. Ironic, and especially testing it with virtual hardware, might benefit from using it. Problem description =================== The main implementation in Ironic of Power and Management interfaces for virtual hardware is SSH driver. It supports several virtualization platforms by making ssh connection to the hypervisor host, executing shell commands and parsing their output. Currently SSH driver supports only SSH transport and only via providing ssh user name and password or private key. Virtual hardware is used mostly in CI/CD environments, and some scenarios require a more flexible solution than SSH driver. Use Case -------- #. CI is deploying an OpenStack cluster on baremetal #. Virtual hardware is provided by a separate hypervisor node owned by the CI, not the deployed cluster. #. Security restrictions and other considerations prevent CI owner from creating extra users with SSH access on this standalone hypervisor node, as well as passing in password or private keys for an existing user inside the cluster deployed by CI. #. Some virtualization platforms, like HyperV, does not play nicely with SSH access at all. Proposed change =============== Implement the new Power and Management driver interfaces that are based on ``libvirt-python`` library, which presents a Python API to Libvirt. The main driver property would be the ``libvirt_uri`` similar to SSH driver for ``ssh_virt_type = virsh``. Libvirt is capable of managing many virtualization platforms when provided with the appropriate uri, including those currently supported by SSH driver. It presents a unified API to the virtual hardware, so a single and relatively simple code base will be supporting many virtualization technologies without the need to create and maintain complex sets of bash commands as is the case in SSH driver. The ``libvirt_uri`` is the only parameter that differs for all supported hypervisor types. Another benefit, directly solving the use case outlined in `Problem description`_, is a more flexible choice of command transport Libvirt allows. It includes SSH (over OpenSSH binary or libssh2 library), TLS, unencrypted TCP and unix sockets. Out of these, TLS the most interesting secure alternative to SSH. Alternatives ------------ Re-implement the SSH driver directly. Is surely more risky and involved, plus the name will become misleading. Data model impact ----------------- None State Machine Impact -------------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Client (CLI) impact ------------------- None RPC API impact -------------- None Driver API impact ----------------- None Nova driver impact ------------------ None Security impact --------------- No more that is already present in Ironic and OpenStack at large. * Allows key-less/password-less access to the hypervisor node providing virtual hardware to be configured using other than SSH methods, e.g. SASL. * More options to provide virtual hardware for Ironic. * Introduce possibility to use any libvirt-supported encrypted transport, including SSH and TLS. * Uses Python API bindings for libvirt. The only permissions consideration is that all certificates/keys involved must be accessible for reading to the user owning the ironic-conductor process. * Involves parsing of XML data returned by libvirt from hypervisor. Not sure if a maliciously crafted XML on hypervisor side can be an attack vector. * Resource exhaustion is most likely not a concern, as the same model for connection as in current SSH driver is going to be used. Other end user impact --------------------- None. Scalability impact ------------------ None. Performance Impact ------------------ Performance might be better than with current SSH driver, as it will be running native libvirt code via shallow Python API instead of executing shell commands over Python-implemented Paramiko SSH session. Other deployer impact --------------------- New driver with new config options. Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: vsaienko Other contributors: pshchelo Work Items ---------- - create a new Power and Management driver using ``libvirt-python`` library - provide documentation on how to set it up - (possible future?) re-implement SSH driver to be a simple subclass of Libvirt-driver, keeping the driver properties backward-compatible. Dependencies ============ * `libvirt-python` is already in global requirements Testing ======= Standard ironic tests must pass with this new driver. Separate tempest job might be requested testing the new driver. In the future it might be beneficial to re-implement SSH driver as a subclass of Libvirt-driver, given care is taken to leave driver properties the same. Upgrades and Backwards Compatibility ==================================== No changes in REST or Driver API. Documentation Impact ==================== Document how to setup this driver for various transports/hypervisors. References ========== .. _Libvirt: http://libvirt.org

commit_message:
Add a test bed node for overcloud deployments

Currently there are incompatible services to be deployed
in the overcloud i.e. opencontrail which have dependency
issues with the overcloud controller.

This submission creates a new role called TestBed to deploy
third party and custom services in the overcloud.

How to deploy:

Update the content of environments/testbed.yaml to add the
new services to be deployed/tested in this new role. Then
deploy an overcloud using this env file.

i.e.

openstack overcloud deploy \
--libvirt-type qemu \
--ntp-server pool.ntp.org \
--templates /home/stack/tripleo-heat-templates \
-e /home/stack/tripleo-heat-templates/overcloud-resource-registry-puppet.yaml \
-e /home/stack/tripleo-heat-templates/environments/testbed.yaml

Change-Id: I5bf6ee9eecebda40c0687dfce3582b84d862963c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates refs/changes/01/378301/6 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: heat_template_version: 2016-10-14 description: > OpenStack blank server to hack composable services, configured by Puppet parameters: OvercloudTestBedFlavor: description: Flavor for the test bed nodes to request when deploying. default: baremetal type: string constraints: - custom_constraint: nova.flavor TestBedImage: default: overcloud-full type: string constraints: - custom_constraint: glance.image KeyName: default: default description: Name of an existing Nova key pair to enable SSH access to the instances type: string UpdateIdentifier: default: '' type: string description: > Setting to a previously unused value during stack-update will trigger package update on all nodes ServiceNetMap: default: {} description: Mapping of service_name -> network name. Typically set via parameter_defaults in the resource registry. type: json EndpointMap: default: {} description: Mapping of service endpoint -> protocol. Typically set via parameter_defaults in the resource registry. type: json Hostname: type: string default: '' # Defaults to Heat created hostname HostnameMap: type: json default: {} description: Optional mapping to override hostnames ExtraConfig: default: {} description: | Additional hiera configuration to inject into the cluster. Note that ObjectStorageExtraConfig takes precedence over ExtraConfig. type: json ObjectStorageExtraConfig: default: {} description: | Role specific additional hiera configuration to inject into the cluster. type: json TestBedIPs: default: {} type: json NetworkDeploymentActions: type: comma_delimited_list description: > Heat action when to apply network configuration changes default: ['CREATE'] SoftwareConfigTransport: default: POLL_SERVER_CFN description: | How the server should receive the metadata required for software configuration. type: string constraints: - allowed_values: [POLL_SERVER_CFN, POLL_SERVER_HEAT, POLL_TEMP_URL, ZAQAR_MESSAGE] CloudDomain: type: string description: > The DNS domain used for the hosts. This should match the dhcp_domain configured in the Undercloud neutron. Defaults to localdomain. ServerMetadata: default: {} description: > Extra properties or metadata passed to Nova for the created nodes in the overcloud. It's accessible via the Nova metadata API. type: json ObjectStorageSchedulerHints: type: json description: Optional scheduler hints to pass to nova default: {} NodeIndex: type: number default: 0 ServiceConfigSettings: type: json default: {} ServiceNames: type: comma_delimited_list default: [] MonitoringSubscriptions: type: comma_delimited_list default: [] ConfigCommand: type: string description: Command which will be run whenever configuration data changes default: os-refresh-config --timeout 14400 LoggingSources: type: json default: [] LoggingGroups: type: comma_delimited_list default: [] resources: TestBed: type: OS::Nova::Server metadata: os-collect-config: command: {get_param: ConfigCommand} properties: image: {get_param: TestBedImage} flavor: {get_param: OvercloudTestBedFlavor} key_name: {get_param: KeyName} networks: - network: ctlplane user_data_format: SOFTWARE_CONFIG user_data: {get_resource: UserData} name: str_replace: template: {get_param: Hostname} params: {get_param: HostnameMap} software_config_transport: {get_param: SoftwareConfigTransport} metadata: {get_param: ServerMetadata} scheduler_hints: {get_param: ObjectStorageSchedulerHints} # Combine the NodeAdminUserData and NodeUserData mime archives UserData: type: OS::Heat::MultipartMime properties: parts: - config: {get_resource: NodeAdminUserData} type: multipart - config: {get_resource: NodeUserData} type: multipart # Creates the "heat-admin" user if configured via the environment # Should return a OS::Heat::MultipartMime reference via OS::stack_id subject: Remove environment data from task inbound context
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-09-29 05:03:49.000000000', 'files': ['mistral/engine/tasks.py', 'mistral/workflow/base.py', 'mistral/engine/workflows.py', 'mistral/services/workflows.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/mistral/commit/d9e734fa5b399bd72eff8c06e0264c2661cce4f6', 'message': "Remove environment data from task inbound context

* It's redundant to keep environment data in task inbound context,
  it is immutable and we can always take it from workflow execution
  object which is more efficient from DB space consumption
  standpoint. The only case when it's allowed to modify data
  in a workflow environment is when we either resume or re-run
  a workflow and in this case we can change it for the whole
  workflow execution.

Change-Id: I244c1768aaa306f8ad41084325107a40005d874c
(cherry picked from commit bdf49b7193383b8e5ac8aed4d3a36c6be96e6040)
"}]
commit_message:
Remove environment data from task inbound context

* It's redundant to keep environment data in task inbound context,
  it is immutable and we can always take it from workflow execution
  object which is more efficient from DB space consumption
  standpoint. The only case when it's allowed to modify data
  in a workflow environment is when we either resume or re-run
  a workflow and in this case we can change it for the whole
  workflow execution.

Change-Id: I244c1768aaa306f8ad41084325107a40005d874c
(cherry picked from commit bdf49b7193383b8e5ac8aed4d3a36c6be96e6040)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/31/379131/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add tests to check deletion of delayed calls on WF execution delete

Change-Id: Ibaef5c255d233348a845b47247dd448119b241cd
Closes-Bug: #1627443
(cherry picked from commit a7830dc6ccfca5d5c482dc6382f465e0e94c90ce)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/29/379129/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def delete_join_completion_check_on_execution_delete(self): wf_text = """--- version: '2.0' wf: tasks: task1: action: std.noop on-success: join_task task2: description: Never ends action: std.async_noop on-success: join_task join_task: join: all """ wf_service.create_workflows(wf_text) wf_ex = self.engine.start_workflow('wf', {}) tasks = db_api.get_task_executions(workflow_execution_id=wf_ex.id) self.assertTrue(len(tasks) >= 2) task1 = self._assert_single_item(tasks, name='task1') self.await_task_success(task1.id) # Once task1 is finished we know that join_task must be created. tasks = db_api.get_task_executions(workflow_execution_id=wf_ex.id) self._assert_single_item( tasks, name='join_task', state=states.WAITING ) calls = db_api.get_delayed_calls() mtd_name = 'mistral.engine.task_handler._refresh_task_state' self._assert_single_item(calls, target_method_name=mtd_name) # Stop the workflow. db_api.delete_workflow_execution(wf_ex.id) self._await( lambda: len(db_api.get_delayed_calls(target_method_name=mtd_name)) == 0 )
